awd_titl_txt: Center for the Environmental Implications of NanoTechnology (CEINT)
awd_abstract_narration:
Duke University 
http://www.ceint.duke.edu/

Institutional Partners:
Baylor University
Carnegie Mellon University 
Howard University 
Stanford University 
University of Kentucky 
Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University 

This award continues funding of a Center to conduct research and education on the environmental impacts of nanomaterials. The Center goals are to advance discovery of general principles that determine the movement and transformation of nanomaterials in the environment and their effects on organisms and ecosystems. The Center further aims to translate this knowledge into the language of risk assessment to guide nanotechnology in ways that minimize harm to the environment. This Center engages a highly interdisciplinary, multi-institutional team in integrated research to establish a theoretical understanding of how the physics and surface chemistry of nanomaterials determine their interactions with the environment, from the molecular level to that of entire ecosystems. The Center will develop new methods for detection and tracking of natural and manufactured nanomaterials in the environment. Information on nanomaterial properties and environmental impacts will be synthesized into models that can be used to predict environmental risk. 

Nanotechnology holds great promise both to the nation's economic growth and to enhance our ability to live in more sustainable ways. However, the responsible implementation of this technology is hampered by uncertainty over the environmental impacts of nanomaterials. There is an urgent societal need to understand this risk, while at the same time providing guidelines for safe design to prevent environmental harm. This Center will conduct the fundamental research necessary to reduce uncertainty in the environmental impacts of nanotechnology. It will contribute uniquely to a network of nanotechnology centers that serve the national needs. The Center will also promote interdisciplinary training of the next generation of nanoscale scientists and engineers in ways that broaden participation in the newly emerging field of environmental nanoscience. In collaboration with national laboratories, non-governmental organizations, and industry, the Center will further research and education goals and engage in outreach that informs both experts and the public at large about the safety issues surrounding nanotechnology

por.por_cntn:
The Center for the Environmental Implications of NanoTechnology (CEINT)  has brought together groups from seven US universities with many other important partners to elucidate general principles that determine nanomaterial behavior and translate this knowledge into the language of risk evaluation to provide guidance in assessing existing and future concerns surrounding the environmental implications of nanomaterials. The overarching goal of CEINT is to unravel the role of nanoparticles in ecosystems, their movements through the environment, their interactions with organisms, the mechanisms by which they exert their influence, and thus, their environmental impacts.

CEINT has made substantial contributions in its research, outreach and education missions. CEINT has produced over 300 peer-reviewed publications listed on its website (ceint.duke.edu), Highlights of this research includes showing clear evidence of nanoparticle-specific effects on organisms and ecosystems and identifying key parameters, or functional assays, that control the spatial and temporal distribution and form of nanomaterials in the environment.  CEINT researchers have shown that nanoscale particles of incidental or natural origin are ubiquitous and often similar or identical to many nanomaterials and demonstrated the essential role of nanomaterial transformations in the environment in determining nanomaterial exposure and effects. Evidence has been published for the critical role of nanoparticle shape and surface chemistry in determining the rate and extent of these transformations. A synthesis of research results is embodied in the context of a framework for forecasting risks that can be used to provide feedback to the nanomaterial producers, regulators, and researchers. CEINT has also developed a mathematical framework for risk forecasting that is easily updated as new information becomes available. In support of its mission, CEINT has led an effort to create the NanoInformatics Knowledge Commons (NIKC) containing curated data on nanoparticle properties, effects, protocols that engaged a broad range of collaborative partners.

CEINT pioneered the use of mesocosms as a means of studying the fate of nanomaterials in highly complex systems. One important result from our mesocosm experiments has been the observation that lab-scale experiments designed to replicate mesocosm results often failed to duplicate the observed mesocosm outcomes.  Mesocosm experiments have revealed NP behavior and toxicity patterns that challenge traditional hypotheses developed in laboratory experiments. We have demonstrated that NP transformations under realistic environmental conditions affect NP reactivity, transport, and toxicity. Significant progress has been made toward 1) characterizing macromolecular coatings and natural organic matter (NOM) on engineered nanoparticles (ENPs) and understanding the effects of those coatings on ENP behavior in the environment, 2) determining the processes affecting interactions of NPs with organisms and with biofilms, 3) measuring and characterizing the types of transformations of ENPs that will occur in the environment and assessing the effect of those transformations to ENP properties, bioavailability, and toxicity potential, 4) understanding the ENP properties that affect attachment to surfaces and developing theory to model those processes, and 5) Determining the distribution and fate of nanomaterials in complex environments.

We have also made progress in understanding the NP properties that affect uptake and biodistribution by both planst and animals, and the movement of nanomaterials through food webs. We have set forth to the NanoEHS community the principle of working form Functional Assays, to achieve near-term predictions of nanoparticle behavior. We have identified key Functional Assays and, in particular, have published methods for determining surface affinity and dissolution rate. Using the C. elegans model we have demonstrated maternal transfer of silver NPs (Ag NPs) to developing embryos, as well as biomagnification. We have evaluated correlations between particle size dissolution rates, coatings, and toxicity. Work on the formation and role of NPs in the environment includes the development of a global budget for inorganic nanomaterials that identifies the sources, sinks, reservoirs, residence and transfer times for such materials. Mechanistic models describing key transport and transformation reactions have been developed and combined with parameter estimation efforts for functional assays to produce global estimates of nanomaterial concentrations in wastewater effluent and biosolids and predictions on where nanomaterials will likely accumulate in the environment.

The outcomes from CEINT?s Education and Public outreach activities have been similarly extensive. CEINT has innovated formal curricula development G9-12, outreach curricula with partner museums and an REU program. The Center has established a diverse cadre of graduate students through aggressive efforts that engage traditionally underrepresented minorities and women. Effective recruitment and retention increased doctoral, masters, undergraduates, and post-docs to a cumulative total of over 275 core trainees. We also graduated an additional 89 REU undergraduates for a total of 360 trainees.  In addition, we mentored 30 high school students and hosted six visiting doctoral students and nine visiting scholars in CEINT labs since funding. Engagement of this large cohort of trainees combined with the substantial evolution in curricula and training opportunities described below has advanced our mission of training the next generation of responsible researchers in environmental nanoscience.


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Mark R Wiesner
